content:
Great contribution, just a bit too wordy.

Here's my solution in Ruby:

p (Math.log2(gets.to_i)+1).floor

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I remembered this story from an old chess book many years ago. You did a great job of turning it into a puzzle. Easy to understand. Not too hard to code.

my algorithm seems different from yours : 

awk '{A=log($0+1)/log(2);print int(A)+(A>int(A))}'

but the two ones pass all tests.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really like the idea and it's not hard to code.  
But please short the text on top just a bit.

Good one but too wordy.
What I propose:
Cut the "Information" section from the statement. It's already present in the Constraints.
Make the statement shorter. You can cut most of the lore.
In the first paragraph, only the description of the reward is worth leaving.
The second paragraph can be cut entirely.
The third one is fine but cut out the second 'now' from it.


Also, your code breaks on F=48 and forward. The trivial solution would still work tho.
Always add corner cases to the test. It'll catch solutions like that and will check your solution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Like it, solved it, approved it

I like the puzzle, but have a few suggestions to improve the description:

The squares on the chess board suddenly become "fields". I would stick to "squares".

"rice grains" change to "rice corns" then back again ("grains" makes more sense).

"amount of [rice corns]" and "amount of [fields]" should be "number of..." (use "number" for things that can be counted, "amount" for things that cannot)

There are 2^63 grains of rice on the last square of the chess board.
This single square has enough rice for any input, so the output should always be 1.
I think you need to add "*starting with the first square*, how many squares..."
I am not a pro chess player but still a interesting level
Using logarithm makes your work easier!
Because the author changed for the last paragraph, see this for the squares: https://purposefocuscommitment.medium.com/the-rice-and-the-chess-board-story-the-power-of-exponential-growth-b1f7bd70aaca
